channel.description: As the sun rises for the Swann family farm within southern Maryland, staff are harvesting corn. Much more precisely, they are picking what is left of a skimpy harvest -- exhausted by a double serving of angry climate. "It will take a couple of years for all of us to get over this,In . says farmer Allen Swann.Allen Swann's family members have been farming this particular land since prior to Civil War. This individual doesn't remember a more difficult year, studies CBS News Surgeon Bob Orr. First, the choking drought turned your fields to dirt, making it impossible in order to plant grain. Then record rains coming from Hurricanes Dennis and Floyd struggling the back-up crops."We rooted a lot of sweet corn and a lot of tomatoes late, to compensate for what many of us lost because of the shortage," Swann says. "And next all this rain comes along and we're going for a hit on this too."It was a hit associated with some $20,000 * $30,000. Across The usa, agricultural losses are generally staggering: $1.3 billion dollars from the Eastern famine. $400 million more through floods in the North plains. And, $1 billion dollars and still counting from this summer's hurricanes."I'd say it is certainly a bad year,In . says Dan Glickman, the particular U.S. Receptionist of Agriculture.As well as, Glickman says, it comes at a very bad time. Prices are already depressed as a consequence of bumper crops of late."This year you have bad crops, you have weak harvests in many places across the United States, however you have worldwide surpluses,Inches he says. "So you end up with the worst of both worlds. You have bad crops and bad price ranges." Crop insurance and disaster grants will cover some of the losses. Low-interest emergency loans might help. "We probably lost regarding 60 - 70 per cent," Swann says.But farmers such as Allen Swann will still glance at the pain as they walk their ravaged fields and also wonder what the subsequent growing season brings.
